Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Supernova Cosmology and the Changing Sky
Award.AbstractNarration:
Dr. Saurabh Jha (Rutgers University New Brunswick) will carry out a long-term plan of integrated research and education to firm up the foundations of supernova cosmology, put Type Ia supernovae (SNe Ia) to a new use as a tool to study dark matter, and prepare the next generation of astronomers for new research methods to study the changing sky. As the samples of supernovae discovered by current and planned surveys grow, the precision of constraints on dark energy parameters hits a floor of systematic uncertainty. Dr. Jha will study the major limiting factors, with a goal of reducing current systematics by (1) characterizing the supernova (SN) host-galaxy dust extinction, (2) identifying more robust and precise subsamples of SNe Ia, and (3) constraining SN Ia progenitors, explosion models, and luminosity evolution through the study of peculiar objects. In addition, Dr. Jha will bring these cosmological tools to bear on a new problem: studying the dark matter distribution in clusters of galaxies using lensed SNe Ia whose absolute magnification can be measured in current surveys and planned observations with Rutgers' share of the Southern African Large Telescope. These projects will lay the groundwork for comprehensive studies of supernovae and time-domain astrophysics in general with the Large Synoptic Survey Telescope as the results from this program will directly impact the design and execution of future supernova cosmology surveys.

Dr. Jha will also integrate this research into his and Rutgers' educational mission, with a primary focus on upper-division classes for science majors. Dr. Jha plans to bring peer-learning techniques to an unusually large (50 students) third-year calculus-based introduction to astrophysics class, introduce problems based on current research with real data into the curriculum, and have students write archival research proposals on topics in time-domain astrophysics. Dr. Jha will also recruit undergraduates for summer research projects, with an emphasis on students from underrepresented groups who may not otherwise consider career options in basic research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: The research focus of the project was on the use of type Ia supernovae as distance indicators for cosmology, the study of "peculiar" white dwarf supernovae, and the study of gravitationally lensed supernovae as a tool to measure absolute magnifications. The award supported some part of my work in 50 publications. 

Research highlights led by our group at Rutgers include: 

1. The discovery of the first progenitor system of a white dwarf supernova and studies of "type Iax" supernovae, supporting a failed disruption model (McCully, Jha, et al. 2014, ApJ, 786, 134; McCully, Jha, et al. 2014, Nature, 512, 54).

2. Measurement of a high-redshift type Ia supernovae lensed by a foreground galaxy cluster, directly and independently testing and confirming the predicted magnification (Patel, McCully, Jha, et al. 2014, ApJ, 786, 9).

Other research highlights in coauthored papers include:

1. Cosmological results and final data release from the SDSS-II SN Survey (Kessler et al. 2009, ApJS, 185, 32; Sako et al. 2014, ApJS, submitted; arXiv:1401.3317).

2. A 3% measurement of the Hubble constant from Cepheids and type Ia supernovae (Riess et al. 2011, ApJ, 730, 119).

3. Stringent limits on the progenitor system of the nearby type Ia supernova 2011fe in M101 (Li et al. 2011, Nature, 480, 348).

4. Identification of type Iax supernovae as a new class of white dwarf supernova (Foley et al. 2013, ApJ, 767, 57).

5. Joint Lightcurve Analysis cosmological results (Betoule et al. 2014, A&A, 568, A22).

 

Broader Impacts: The award provided support for training of two graduate students (Dr. Curtis McCully, now a postdoc at LCOGT/UCSB, and Dr. Brandon Patel (now in the private sector) and five undergraduates: Dr. Ben Shappee (now a Carnegie-Princeton-Hubble fellow), Mr. Joey Rodriguez (graduate student in astronomy at Vanderbilt and Lehigh), Ms. Samia Bouzid (awarded a Fulbright grant, and now working in the private sector), Mr. Tom Holoien (now an Ohio State astronomy Ph.D. student), and Mr. Viraj Pandya (now a masters' student in astronomy in a "Bridge" program at Princeton).

In addition to numerous public outreach talks, this program supported the development of active learning techniques and conceptual understanding in an advanced undergraduate class for majors, "Principles of Astrophysics." This work was led by a graduate student in the Rutgers School of Education, Ms. Heather Rave, in collaboration with Profs. Eugenia Etkina and Eric Gawiser and resulted in a conference presentation at the 2012 summer meeting of the American Association of Physics Teachers (Rave, Gawiser, Jha, & Etkina 2012, "Improving Student Understanding of Astrophysics Concepts," AAPT summer meeting, Philadelphia, PA).
